title: Ivan Milat's family refuse to believe he murdered seven backpackers - and say they have evidence
text:
Ivan Milat's family refused to believe he was responsible for murdering seven backpackers right up until his death.

Milat, 74, who is suspected of killing dozens of others but never confessed to any crimes, died of throat cancer at 4.07am on Sunday in Sydney's Long Bay jail.

'He was an all-round nice bloke. We don't believe for one second that he did it,' Bill Milat, 72, one of Ivan's nine brothers, told the Daily Telegraph.

The brother claimed to have evidence which accounted for Milat's whereabouts on Boxing Day 1991, the same day German backpackers Gabor Neugebauer, 21, and Anja Habscied, 20, left a hostel in Kings Cross and then vanished.

'There were three cars parked behind his, he couldn't have got out that day... We were there all day, we have photo's,' Bill said.

Bill Milat (left) always believed his brother Ivan (right) was innocent

The family claim they have evidence which accounts for Ivan's whereabouts on Boxing Day 1991, the same day German backpackers Gabor Neugebauer (right), 21, and Anja Habscied (left), 20, left a hostel in Kings Cross and then vanished

Bill also insisted the evidence from Paul Onions, a British traveller who escaped Milat as he tried to tie him up at gun point in Mittagong on January 25, 1990, was false.

'Paul Onions said there was a spare wheel on the back of his car … he never had a spare wheel on the back,' Bill said.

Milat's nephew, Alistair Shipsey, 60, also believed Ivan was innocent and stored a string of letters sent from his uncle while locked up.

The letters were signed off with 'Ivan', a stick-finger drawing of a saint and the word 'innocent'.

'If you read all the letters, 24 years of letters, his passion's there. I know he's innocent,' Mr Shipsey told 10Daily in May.

'I know he's innocent and I know he's been framed, 100 per cent, otherwise I wouldn't stick my head out here,' he said.

Milat had been taken to hospital in May to be treated for cancer of the oesophagus and stomach before later being returned to the hospital wing of the jail.

The cancer spread to his liver, lungs, bones and lymph nodes, and he developed fluid on his heart.

Mr Shipsey accurately predicted there would be no 11th-hour confession from Milat.

Milat's nephew, Alistair Shipsey (pictured), 60, also believed Ivan was innocent and stored numerous letters sent from his uncle while locked up

Milat was convicted in 1996 for the murder of seven backpackers in the Belanglo State Forest, south of Sydney, between 1989 and 1992

Milat was convicted in 1996 for the murder of seven backpackers in the Belanglo State Forest, south of Sydney, between 1989 and 1992.

He was serving seven life sentences for the killings but always maintained his innocence and refused to confess to the other deaths that police believed he was responsible for.

Milat was found guilty of the killings of English backpackers Caroline Clarke, 21, and Joanne Walters, 22, Melbourne couple James Gibson and Deborah Everist, both 19 and German backpackers Simone Schmidl, 20, Gabor Neugebauer, 21, and Anja Habschied, 20.

He stabbed most of his victims - decapitating one whose head has never been found - and shot another 10 times in the head as if using her for target practice.
description: The Milats claim they have evidence which accounts for Ivan's whereabouts on Boxing Day 1991, the same day two left a hostel in Kings Cross and then vanished.
authors: Chris Lines For Daily Mail Australia
